#Text=Legend of Diego Salcedo
#Text=Diego Salcedo ( died 1511 ) was a semi-legendary Spanish conquistador who is said to have lived during the colonization of the Americas . [ 1 ]
#Text=According to legend , his death at the hands of the indigenous Taíno people ignited the Taíno rebellion of 1511 .
#Text=Salcedo 's death

#Text=According to the story , Salcedo died in 1511 , during a trip to Puerto Rico , when Taínos , under the command of Agüeybaná II ( brother of the great Taino Cacique Agüeybaná ) and the Cacique of Añasco , Urayoán , drowned him in the Río Grande de Añasco .
#Text=Historically , two versions about how Salcedo was lured to his death have collided .

#Text=Many books assert that the soldier had been told he 'd be taken to a lake filled with Taíno women that he could have sex with , and , once there , he found not women , but men who then proceeded to drown him .

#Text=The other version has Salcedo being offered a ride across a river by Taínos who carried him on their arms , and then drowned him and kept him for days , afraid he 'd still be alive and waiting until they were certain he was dead .
#Text=A third , and most accepted version of Salcedo 's death says that the Tainos , fearing that the Spaniards might be gods , refrained from harming them .
#Text=After suffering under the Spaniards for so long , the Tainos , by order of Agüeybaná , ambushed Salcedo as he was drinking water at the edge of a river .

#Text=Fearing that Salcedo might resurrect after three days — based on their understanding of the Christian teachings wielded by Catholic priests — they sat around for three days waiting for Salcedo to come back from the dead , but all they saw was Salcedo 's body rotting due to the heat just as they would .
#Text=At that moment the Tainos realized that these were no gods .
#Text=It was with Salcedo 's death that the Taínos were encouraged to declare war on the Spaniards in Puerto Rico .
#Text=This led to the Taino rebellion of 1511 .
#Text=However , the Tainos were quickly defeated due to the Spaniards ' better weaponry and war expertise .
#Text=After the death of Agüeybaná II , the native warriors retracted and became disorganized . [ 2 ]
#Text=Agüeybaná II 's followers opted for engaging the Spaniards via guerilla tactics . [ 2 ]
#Text=Such guerilla warfare lasted for the next eight years , until 1519 . [ 3 ]
#Text=A second round of raids erupted in 1513 when Ponce de Leon departed the island to explore Florida .
#Text=The settlement of Caparra , the seat of the island government at that time , was sacked and burned by an alliance between Taínos and natives from the northeastern Antilles . [ 4 ]
#Text=By 1520 the Taíno presence on the island had almost disappeared .
#Text=A government census in 1530 reports the existence of only 1,148 Taínos remaining in Puerto Rico . [ 5 ]
#Text=However , oppressive conditions for the surviving Taíno continued .
#Text=Many of those who stayed on the island soon died either due to cruel treatment or the smallpox epidemic , which attacked the island in 1519 . [ 6 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Legend
#Text=A local-legend tells of a ghostly Taino woman , supposedly Salcedo 's lover , that still haunts the site of his drowning at present-day Añasco .
#Text=This belief is exemplified by a verse in the town 's anthem :
#Text=Salcedo
#Text=in popular culture
#Text=Salcedo is referenced in a song of Puerto Rican rock band Fiel a la Vega .

#Text=The song is titled " El Asunto : Salcedo Sigue Siendo Mortal " ( The Issue : Salcedo is still a Mortal ) and it makes a comparison between the Spaniards ' rule in the island and the United States ' invasion of 1898 .
